I wonder if smaller animals have brains that can process information faster than us, and larger animals have brains that can process information slower. Imagine a giant human trying to walk, the legs would be physically constrained by the acceleration that the muscles can provide, and because they are so big, the limb movements would have to be slow. If you think of ants, bumblebees, and hummingbirds, they all move very rapidly even though they are smaller, so I wonder if our conciousnesses or thought processing is fundamentally slower. Cool stuff.

Destin, you must have a certain titanium quotient about you to pull off a stunt like that. Those little birds must operate on a mental frequency about a hundred hertz faster than our own, so what seems impossibly fast for us to follow, must be for them, like life in the slow lane. Still, just to be on the safe side of prudent, I feel I would be remiss if I did not recommend that in the future you wear a good pair of safety glasses before interacting with any nearby flying objects that have a mind of their own. 

While you may wear contacts and don't need the 4-eyes stigma that comes with eyeglass wearers, I'm sure you do want to practice good science protocol behaviors both in and outside of the traditional laboratory environment. 

I loved watching the hummingbird hover in slow-motion. I was looking for the classic "figure-8" rotational aspect of the birds shoulder movements and the scribing of the wing-tips but was unable to discern this pattern? What was I not seeing in the film footage that I should have? I saw what looked mostly to me like wing oscillation front to back with the tail feathers vectoring the displaced air as necessary to stabilize and control the pitch and yaw movements made at the volitionary discretion of your feathery friend. 

Have you ever done a "Phantom tribute" to the common Water Strider (Gerridae)? I would like to see how they handle "Denny's paradox" and move so quickly?
With which program edit your slow motion videos?

Destin, having finally gotten the chance to see the hummingbird episode, I feel it's due that someone give their input on why perhaps this video hasn't been as successful as you hoped it might have been.

Upon watching it, while I knew the whole while what it was leading up to, multiple times you alluded to a) the aggression sparse resources can elicit in hummingbirds and b) that you were going to taper the supply of resources, which may give the wrong impression about the ethics of your proposed experiment. Secondly, while a valuable lesson in economics and ecology, you spent very little time explaining why the supply and demand curves appear the way they do and why the experiment being done was equivalent to a shift as you illustrated. I feel like this video was perhaps deviant from your usual style of "learning along with the audience", as it's readily apparent that you knew exactly what was going on throughout. Lastly, nothing done here required the use of hummingbirds at all – the experiment would have been equivalent with any animals in a controlled ecosystem. It was almost slow motion-baity, without using the high speed camera to analyze much of anything.

That being said, I still loved it and think you're adorable and an awesome educator :) I know you put a lot of hard work into this, but I feel like you could have better shown your awesomeness in a more complete video or video series in your usual style

I would like to see more slow motion of their fights on the internet, but that's not why I'm commenting. I have a question that you might be able to answer if you are interested. In water polo we often try to confuse the goalies with a "skip shot". Performed correctly, the ball will hit the water and bounce up at a surprisingly sharp angle, but a small error in the throw will cause the ball to either skip across the surface at a very low angle, or, even worse, stop completely. I want to know what that difference is. As a pretty talented lifeguard, swim instructor, springboard diver, swimmer, and water polo player, I could discuss the physics of all these sports with you for quite some time. Please let me know if this is something you could answer for me or not.

How does the hummingbird at 3:05 go from a hovering position to having forward momentum using only its body without changing the orientation or flapping pattern of its wings? It seems that its tail interacting with the fast moving are created by the flapping wings to propel the bird.

It actually looks like the bird is using the tail like a sail on a ship. Sometimes it moves the tail so that it seems the air would push against the tail feathers, moving the bird backward (a sailboat sailing with the wind, with the wind filling the sail from behind). Then sometimes, like when it's hovering and tipping forward at 3:30, it curves the tail and seems to be using it to gain lift like an airfoil (a sailboat moving against the wind and using the airfoil design to create a sort of "horizontal lift"). I would love to see one of these guys free flying in a visible fluid in slow motion that showed how it all works.
Starting at 3:04, it's amazing how the bird keeps its head steady. The body moves, but not the head, and this is slow motion. Get smarter every day.
